SENT.plain: The brain of a child with Down syndrome (DS) and vascular abnormalities is described
Neuropathological examination showed a large cerebral infarction

In the circle of Willis there was hypoplasia of the left middle and posterior communicating cerebral arteries, and microscopically there was thickening of intima and focal disruption of internal elastica in some areas of the circle of Willis
Several reports suggest that the incidence of moyamoya disease is higher in children with DS than in other children

The high incidence of congenital heart disease in DS suggests an abnormality of vascular development that may manifest intracranially as a structural vascular defect, creating a vulnerability to unknown factors important in the pathogenesis of the moyamoya abnormality
